Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support participation by U.S. students and junior researchers the conference CiE 2011 (Models of Computation in Context), to be held in June/July of 2011 in Sofia, Bulgaria. This meeting is organized by the research group in Mathematical Logic at Sofia university in conjunction with the Association for Computability in Europe, a community of more than 700 researchers, including about 100 members from the United States.

This annual conference series promotes the development of computability-related science, ranging over mathematics, computer science, and applications in various natural and engineering sciences such as physics and biology. The conference scope also includes the study of philosophy and history of computing as it relates to questions of computability.

Computability has played a crucial role in mathematics and computer science, leading to the discovery, understanding and classification of decidable/undecidable problems and paving the way for the modern computer era. Recent new paradigms of computation, based on biological and physical models, address in a radically new way questions of efficiency and challenge assumptions about the so-called Turing barrier.

CiE 2011 will bring context, multidisciplinary perspective and computability-theoretic focus to a wide spectrum of disciplines -- including computer science, mathematics and logic, physics and quantum theory, biology and informatics, linguistics and philosophy, neuroscience and learning theory.

The conference CiE 2011 (Models of Computation in Context), took place
from June 27 to July 2, 2011 in Sofia, Bulgaria. The meeting was
organized by the research group in Mathematical Logic at Sofia
university in conjunction with the Association for Computability in
Europe, a community of more than 700 researchers, including about 100
members from the United States.

theory, biology and informatics, linguistics and philosophy,
neuroscience and learning theory.


The conference featured tutorials by Jack Lutz on Effective Fractal Dimensions and by Geoffrey Pullum on Linguistics for Computability Theorists. There were 7 plenary talks:

(1)  Christel Baier: Quantitative Analysis of Randomized
 Distributed Systems and Probabilistic Automata

(2)  Michiel van Lambalgen: Logic in a neuroscience lab

(3)  Florian Markowetz: Integrative analysis of breast cancer

(4) Antonio Montalban: The Jump of a Structure 

(5) Alexandra Shlapentokh: Undecidability and Definitions of Integers and Itegral Functions

(6)  Theodore Slaman: The First-order Fragments of Second-order Theories 

(7) Alasdari Urquhart: Goedel, von Neumann and the origins of theoretical computer science

There were six special sessions:

(1)  Computational Linguistics

(2) Relations between the physical world and formal models of
computation

(3)  Natural Computing

(4)  Computability in Analysis, Algebra and Geometry.

(5) Classical Computability Theory

(6) Theory of Transfinite Computations

Many publications on these topics resulted from the conference. A
volume of abstracts and handouts was published by the host
university and 33 selected papers were published in a volume entitled
Models of Computation in Context, published in the Springer series Lecture Notes in Computer Science. An issue of the journal Annals of Pure and Applied Logic featured 9 articles arising from the conference.
